awd_titl_txt: STTR Phase I:  A Reinforcement Learning-Based Automated Self-Guiding Drilling Tool
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Program Phase I (STTR) project is to provide an environmentally friendly, sustainable, and cost-effective access to energy by improving information flow during drilling processes.  The US geothermal energy industry is expected to grow by 48% to $6.8 billion by 2026 and will benefit from the significant savings of drilling activities, which currently constitute 40-60% of the costs of the entire geothermal plant and field development.  In addition, oil and gas (O&G) drilling operations will benefit from faster and cleaner operations. 

This STTR Phase I project addresses the inability to transmit large amounts of data from downhole to the surface by performing most of the processing at the drill-bit. The proposed state-of-the-art drilling tool incorporates advanced processing power and intelligence downhole.  It is built on physics-based machine learning algorithms centered on Reinforcement Learning (RL) techniques, used previously in complex problems such as autonomous vehicles and lunar landing. The system will model the highly complex drilling environment as a Markov Decision Process, then trained on supercomputing facilities and validated in a laboratory-scale drilling setup using off-the-shelf electronics. This project will lead to an automated sequential decision-making process in drilling.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer Program Phase I (STTR) project is to provide an environmentally friendly, sustainable, and cost-effective access to energy by improving information flow during drilling processes. The US geothermal energy industry is expected to grow by 48% to $6.8 billion by 2026 and will benefit from the significant savings of drilling activities, which currently constitute 40-60% of the costs of the entire geothermal plant and field development. In addition, oil and gas (O&G) drilling operations will benefit from faster and cleaner operations.

This STTR Phase I project addresses the inability to transmit large amounts of data from downhole to the surface by performing most of the processing at the drill-bit. The proposed state-of-the-art drilling tool incorporates advanced processing power and intelligence downhole. It is built on physics-based machine learning algorithms centered on Reinforcement Learning (RL) techniques, used previously in complex problems such as autonomous vehicles and lunar landings. The system models the highly complex drilling environment as a Markov Decision Process, which is then trained on high-performance computing facilities and validated using off-the-shelf electronics. The proposed technology will pave the way for the next level of automated and intelligent applications in the Oil & Gas and geothermal energy industry.

The geosteering of a hydrocarbon or geothermal well involves taking decisions regarding the placement of the well in the target zone by accurately steering the wellbore while drilling. This process, when combined with sometimes conflicting objectives of ROP optimization, or minimizing wellbore tortuosity, brings in a multitude of operational challenges. Traditionally, these operations have been carried out in a manual fashion predominantly relying on the personnel's expertise and experience. Several gaps were identified in the current methods such as the process being reactive with decision-making at prolonged intervals of typically 90 feet, the reliance on modeling complex uncertainties such as bit-walk, and the limitations on translating the methods to more current methodologies such as the use of a rotary steerable system. These gaps are addressed in this project through an alternative approach of utilizing data-driven artificial intelligence techniques such as reinforcement learning, through a self-learning approach in an interactive environment to better utilize the breadth of information available both at the surface and downhole to characterize the uncertainties and to provide better solutions for this multi-objective problem.

While it is possible to run the AI models on the surface, the real value of the technology can be realized by performing edge computing at the bit, therefore enabling autonomous self-steering drilling through this process. This is because communicating the drilling data from several thousands of feet down-hole to the EDR up-hole is very slow (0-6 bps) which limits the available bandwidth. This problem has hindered the adoption of automated solutions. High-speed communication alternatives are underway but are still in the early adoption phase of their development. They are not economically viable for mass adoption on lower-cost wells, especially on the onshore and geothermal markets. On the other hand, there is no downhole equipment in the industry today that can handle the high processing needs of advanced artificial intelligence models. This has led to the development of a proprietary downhole tool in-house that is equipped with state-of-the-art processing capabilities during the first phase of the project. Functional tests were conducted bench-top to evaluate the performance of the board in running the AI inference models. The hardware prototype successfully handled the computing functions required to drill a well autonomously.


Last Modified: 07/15/2022
Modified by: Enrique Zarate Losoya
